definitions.definition: to hit somebody/something with your foot

examples.text: Stop kicking—it hurts!
She was punched and kicked by her attackers.
The boys were **kicking a ball** around in the yard.
Vandals had kicked the door down.
She had to kick the door open because her hands were full.
She kicked at the loose pebbles by the roadside.
Don't kick the ball too hard.
He was sent off for deliberately kicking an Italian player.
They threw him to the ground and kicked him hard in the stomach.
Marcia gently kicked the horse again to make it trot.
She could feel the baby kicking against her stomach wall.
Abe roared and kicked over a table.
She kicked me on the knee.
Suddenly the far door was kicked open.
He got up angrily and kicked the chair over.

definitions.definition: to move your legs as if you were kicking something

examples.text: The child was dragged away, **kicking and screaming**.
The dancers kicked their legs in the air.
He rolled over in the sand, kicking wildly.
I tried to dive back under, kicking with my legs.
I was carried upstairs, arms waving and legs kicking.
The little boy was now lying on his back kicking his legs in the air.

definitions.definition: to be annoyed with yourself because you have done something stupid, missed an opportunity, etc.

examples.text: He'll kick himself when he finds out he could have had the job.
I could kick myself for being so stupid.
I mentally kicked myself for missing such an opportunity.

definitions.definition: to score points by kicking the ball

examples.text: to **kick a penalty/goal**
He **kicked** 23 **points**, ensuring victory for New Zealand.

definitions.definition: to stop doing something harmful that you have done for a long time

examples.text: He had been smoking for 15 years and wanted to **kick the habit**.
to kick drugs/the booze

definitions.definition: very active, healthy or popular

examples.text: My mother is still alive and kicking.

definitions.definition: to hit somebody/something very hard

examples.text: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

definitions.definition: to act in a way that is aggressive or full of energy
to succeed or win in an impressive way
to punish or defeat somebody
to die
to delay dealing with a problem

examples.text: This is another attempt to kick the can down the road and leave it to the next generation.

definitions.definition: to have nothing to do while you are waiting for somebody/something

examples.text: We were kicking our heels, waiting for some customers.

definitions.definition: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all

examples.text: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

definitions.definition: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it
to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem

examples.text: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

definitions.definition: to start to behave badly and refuse to accept any discipline or control
to test the quality of something to see whether it is suitable for you before you buy it
to complain loudly about something

examples.text: They’ll usually give you your money back if you threaten to kick up a stink.

definitions.definition: to be relaxed and enjoy yourself
to move somebody to a job that seems to be more important but that actually has less power or influence
to continue to hurt somebody when they are already defeated, etc.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: of unknown origin.
